Equivalence and exhaustion

In the previous section we have seen that we can prove implications of the form \(A \implies B\) by use of deductive reasoning in direct proof. In this section we will look at how we can prove equivalences. Recall that we say two statements \(A\) and \(B\) are equivalent (written \(A \iff B\) read \(A\) if and only if \(B\)) if both \(A \implies B\) and \(B \implies A\). A proof that involves proving an equivalence is sometimes called an if and only if proof, referencing the equivalence of the statements \(A\) and \(B\). We shall see that in order to have a valid if and only if proof we must prove both implications or directions.


Example

Lemma: Suppose that \(n=10a+b\), where \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_+\). Prove that \(n\) is a multiple of \(9\) iff (a+b) is a multiple of \(9\).
1.
Notice that a positive integer being multiple of \(9\) means that it can be written in the form \(9k\), where \(k \in \mathbb{Z}\). So the above statement is saying: \[ n = 9k \iff (a+b) = 9l \]
2.
We shall prove the \("\implies"\) direction first, that is, we will show \(n = 9k \implies (a+b) = 9l.\)
3.
So, suppose that \(n = 9k\), then \[ 9k = 10a+b = 9a + a + b = 9a + (a+b). \]
4.
Then rearranging, we have \[ a+ b = 9k - 9a = 9(k-a). \]
5.
Therefore by definition, \(a+b\) is a multiple of \(9\) and we have proved the forward direction (that is, we have proved that \(n = 9k \implies (a+b) = 9l.))
4.
We must now prove the reverse direction (that is, we must prove that \((a+b) = 9l \implies n = 9k\).)
5.
So suppose that \((a+b) = 9l\) then, \[ n = 10a + b = 9a + (a + b) = 9a + 9l = 9(a+l) \]
6.
Hence, \(n\) is a multiple of \(9\) and we have proved the reverse direction. Since we have proved both directions, the proof is complete.
